comment: This is the game that convinced me that I hate blind bidding.
Blind bidding and take that cards. I'm out.

For me, fell to the big drawback of multiplayer blind-bid games ("surprise! you lose.") And the large variation in spell power sat uneasily with the rest of the game.

Redeeming factor: Hey, it's by Richard Breese!

Its way too long for what it is
Also some of the cards are way too mean
The game is way too random for how long and frustrating it is

[December 2021]
I was interested in this game because it has quite some cool mechanisms and looks like it has a nice game flow. But I didn't enjoy playing it. Blind bidding, take that actions, there is just too much chaos that can mess up your plan. And you do it four times in a row.

I went in thinking this was a strategy game, but it is actually a beer and pretzel game. Even as a beer and pretzel game, I think this one is mediocre. Would rather play something like Libertalia or RoboRally.

Re-implements: Keydom

2003 Nederlandse Spellenprijs Nominee
2001 International Gamers Awards - General Strategy; Multi-player Nominee
2001 Games Magazine Game of the Year Winner
2000 Meeples Choice Award Nominee

A good light game with some legs to it. A nice intro to worker placement with use of powers and cards. That and the blind bidding keeps it entertaining for all.
Top tip: take an artefact from each pile blind and return to the box - adds mystery and keeps the length down.
Extremely exciting worker placement game with lots of interaction, quickly explained rules and a pleasant playing time. Great!
